Chapter XV.—"Gazetteer" "Nugur taluk."

This taluk is a long narrow strip of land lying on the left bank of the Godāvāri river from the end of the Bhadrachalam taluk for a distance of about 66 miles; it nowhere exceeds 16 miles in width. On one side the deep water channel of the Godāvāri forms its boundary with H.H. the Nizam's territory, on the east and north it marches with Bastar state and its south, and abuts for a distance of 6 miles on Bhadrachalam taluk. It comprises a narrow belt of alluvial land along the river and range of hills ending in a scarp near the Talipera and marking with its highest points the boundary with Bastar. This range is in fact a plateau with precipitous slopes on the western side, down which in the wet weather fall several beautiful cascades; on the eastern side the land falls away gradually to the Bastar territory.

The only river of importance besides the Godāvāri is the Talipera, a broad stream running down, from Bastar and intersecting the taluk, but there are many 'vagus'—hill streams—which, having a short precipitous course to run from the hills to the river, have cut out through the alluvial land deep channels which form a serious impediment to travelling by road.
The cultivation is almost entirely confined to the fertile land along the river margin. There are however a few isolated patches in enclosures in the forests which occupy the greater part of the taluk. Even on the river bank the cultivation is not continuous but is interrupted by forest extending to the water edge. The cultivation is in the main identical with that of Bhadrachalam taluk, the only notable difference being that the 'Podu' cultivation countenanced in Bhadrachalam is strictly prohibited in Nugur. Cholam is the staple crop but there is also a fair amount of paddy, while the cultivation of tobacco in the rich lankas is rapidly extending mainly through the efforts of the ryots from the lower district.

There are no indigenous industries. Older accounts of the taluk make mention of silk culture but there is now no trace of this, although it is still carried on to some extent on H.H. the Nizam's side of the river.

A considerable amount of fish is taken from the Godavari and its affluents, chiefly the Taliperu, but the manner of their capture cannot be commended. The main kinds taken—laboo, mahseer, carnatic and other carp are caught by driving them into a bay with a large net, and then either catching them with a circular cast net or hitting them on the head with sticks. At other places traps of sticks and bamboos are erected while a common trick is, where a suitable place can be found, to enclose the river with small bunds and then poison all the fish with a certain bark. Such methods are extremely destructive particularly as fish of all sizes are taken but the small fry are never of course put back.

The revenue administration is similar in almost all respects to that of Bhadrachalam, although the taluk is still governed by the rules and regulations developed in the Central Provinces, involving the use of terms largely foreign to Nugur. The Koyas of the hills are however more restricted than their brethren of Bhadrachalam. Their "podu" cultivation has long been prohibited and they are not, as their relatives of Bhadrachalam are, allowed to distil as much arrack as they can drink. They must obtain it at the recognised arrack shops. The taluk is divided into two Revenue Inspectors' firkas; there are five patwaris' ranges and a patel and kotwal to each village.

There is at present one superior proprietor of Yelama family over the whole taluk. He resides at Naspur in H.H. the Nizam's territory near Sironcha, and never sets foot in Nugur, for there is a family tradition that he will die, if he crosses a stream a few miles to the north of Venkatapuram. His father and grandfather are both reputed to have perished there.

At about the end of the seventeenth century, the ancestors of the present zamindar obtained possession of the estates which through various vicissitudes have been retained by the family. The major portion of the property is on the Hyderabad side but in the territory handed over to the British, they held the
Surdeshmooks of Sironcha, Nugur, Albaka and Cherla and are now recognised as the superior proprietors of these lands. The estates are in the hands of a Naib under whom in Nugur taluk are three Kamdars, petty ill-paid officials of considerable affluence.

At the time of the settlement by Captain Glasfurd, the local managing agents in Nugur, Albaka and Cherla were recognised as inferior proprietors. They were in effect minor independent chiefs whose main occupation appears to have consisted in raiding the surrounding country, so that in the case of Cherla and Albaka they became the curse of all their neighbours. The family of the Cherla Rajas however died out and no trace remains of them but an evil memory and a few earthen mounds pointed out as the remnant of their fort at Cherla. The superior proprietor bought in the rights of the Albaka Dhorwa and now only the Nugur inferior proprietor remains. This family also was in danger of expiring but the heiress married a Kshatriya from the plains and the disaster was averted. The present inferior proprietor manages the estate in a careful business-like manner and has shown commendable public spirit in the development of Venkatapuram, the head-quarters of the taluk and of his estate.

Venkatapuram.—Situated close to the Gōdāvari is now the taluk head-quarters. The taluk office is in course of construction together with a hospital, a rest-house, a police station and quarters for officers, clerks, constables and peons. The village is being carefully laid out, particularly the new suburb Elwinpeta. A weekly market has been instituted and the village is in a prosperous condition. There is also a Sub-Registrar's office, the head clerk of the taluk being the ex-officio Sub-Registrar.

Cherla.—Once the head-quarters of the inferior proprietor, includes a police station and a post office. Here is also a decayed Saivite temple, the only temple in the taluk, but it is hoped that the institution of a weekly shandy at Glassonpet, a mile from the main village, will restore a little of the faded lustre of this ancient village.
